alert.note: Alert for Johnson; Washington; Wilkinson (Georgia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 01 at 3:13AM EDT until April 01 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Atlanta
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia... Ocmulgee River at Abbeville affecting Dodge, Telfair and Wilcox Counties. Ocmulgee River at US 341 at Hawkinsville affecting Bleckley and Pulaski Counties. Oconee River near Mount Vernon affecting Treutlen, Wheeler and Montgomery Counties. Oconee River at Dublin affecting Washington, Wilkinson, Johnson and Laurens Counties. Oconee River near Oconee affecting Washington, Wilkinson and Johnson Counties. For the Ocmulgee River Basin...including Jackson, Griffin, Juliette, Juliette, Dames Ferry, Macon, Macon, Hawkinsville, Byron, Clinchfield, Hawkinsville, Abbeville, McRae, Scotland, Lumber City... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Oconee River Basin...including Penfield, Milledgeville, Oconee, Oconee, McIntyre, Irwinton, Oconee, Dublin, Mount Vernon... Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Oconee River near Oconee. * WHEN...Until late this afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 18 feet, The water level begins to flood portions of the dirt parking lot area near the Old Balls Ferry Road boat ramp...just upstream and rightbank from the Georgia Highway 57 bridge. Minor flooding continues in the woodlands near the river. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 AM EDT Saturday the stage was 17.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:45 AM EDT Saturday was 20.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this morning and continue falling to 11.3 feet Wednesday evening. - Flood stage is 17 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at weather.gov/atlanta.
